static char __pyx_doc_18nearest_advocate_c_nearest_advocate_single[] = "Post-hoc synchronization method for event-based time-series data.\n    \n    Calculates the synchronicity of two arrays of timestamps in terms of the mean of all minimal distances between each event in arr_sig and its nearest advocate in arr_ref.\n\n    Parameters\n    ----------\n    arr_ref : 1-D ndarray\n        Reference array or timestamps assumed to be correct.\n    arr_sig : 1-D ndarray\n        Signal array of  timestamps, assumed to be shifted by an unknown constant time-delta.\n    dist_max : float\n        Maximal accepted distances between two advocate events. It should be around 1/4 of the median gap of `arr_ref`.\n    regulate_paddings : bool\n        Regulate non-overlapping events in `arr_sig` with a maximum distance of dist_padding, default: True.\n    dist_padding : float\n        Distance assigned to non-overlapping (padding) events. It should be around 1/4 of the median gap of `arr_ref`. Obsolete if `regulate_paddings` is False\n\n    Returns\n    -------\n    mean_dist : float\n        Mean distance between all pairs of advocates, quantity of the synchronicity between the two arrays.\n\n    See Also\n    --------\n    nearest_advocate\n\n    Notes\n    -----\n    .. versionadded:: 1.11.0\n\n    References\n    ----------\n    C. Schranz, S. Mayr, \"Ein neuer Algorithmus zur Zeitsynchronisierung von Ereignis- basierten Zeitreihendaten als Alternative zur Kreuzkorrelation\", Spinfortec (Chemnitz 2022). :doi:`10.5281/zenodo.7370958`\n\n    Examples\n    --------\n    >>> import numpy as np\n    >>> np.random.seed(0)\n    >>> from scipy.signal import nearest_advocate_single_c\n    >>> N = 100_000 \n    >>> DEF_DIST = 0.25    \n    \n    Create a reference array whose events differences are sampled from a normal distribution. The signal array is the reference but shifted by `np.pi` and addional gaussian noise. The event-timestamps of both arrays must be sorted.\n    \n    >>> arr_ref = np.sort(np.cumsum(np.random.normal(loc=1, scale=0.25, size=N))).a""stype(np.float32)\n    >>> arr_sig = np.sort(arr_ref + np.pi + np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=0.1, size=N)).astype(np.float32)\n\n    The function `nearest_advocate_single_c` returns a measure of the synchronicity between both array (lower is better). \n\n    >>> nearest_advocate_single_c(arr_ref=arr_ref, arr_sig=arr_sig, \n                                  dist_max=DEF_DIST, regulate_paddings=True, \n                                  dist_padding=DEF_DIST)\n    0.18436528742313385\n    ";

 007:     """Post-hoc synchronization method for event-based time-series data.
 008:     
 009:     Calculates the synchronicity of two arrays of timestamps in terms of the mean of all minimal distances between each event in arr_sig and its nearest advocate in arr_ref.
 010: 
 011:     Parameters
 012:     ----------
 013:     arr_ref : 1-D ndarray
 014:         Reference array or timestamps assumed to be correct.
 015:     arr_sig : 1-D ndarray
 016:         Signal array of  timestamps, assumed to be shifted by an unknown constant time-delta.
 017:     dist_max : float
 018:         Maximal accepted distances between two advocate events. It should be around 1/4 of the median gap of `arr_ref`.
 019:     regulate_paddings : bool
 020:         Regulate non-overlapping events in `arr_sig` with a maximum distance of dist_padding, default: True.
 021:     dist_padding : float
 022:         Distance assigned to non-overlapping (padding) events. It should be around 1/4 of the median gap of `arr_ref`. Obsolete if `regulate_paddings` is False
 023: 
 024:     Returns
 025:     -------
 026:     mean_dist : float
 027:         Mean distance between all pairs of advocates, quantity of the synchronicity between the two arrays.
 028: 
 029:     See Also
 030:     --------
 031:     nearest_advocate
 032: 
 033:     Notes
 034:     -----
 035:     .. versionadded:: 1.11.0
 036: 
 037:     References
 038:     ----------
 039:     C. Schranz, S. Mayr, "Ein neuer Algorithmus zur Zeitsynchronisierung von Ereignis- basierten Zeitreihendaten als Alternative zur Kreuzkorrelation", Spinfortec (Chemnitz 2022). :doi:`10.5281/zenodo.7370958`
 040: 
 041:     Examples
 042:     --------
 043:     >>> import numpy as np
 044:     >>> np.random.seed(0)
 045:     >>> from scipy.signal import nearest_advocate_single_c
 046:     >>> N = 100_000 
 047:     >>> DEF_DIST = 0.25    
 048:     
 049:     Create a reference array whose events differences are sampled from a normal distribution. The signal array is the reference but shifted by `np.pi` and addional gaussian noise. The event-timestamps of both arrays must be sorted.
 050:     
 051:     >>> arr_ref = np.sort(np.cumsum(np.random.normal(loc=1, scale=0.25, size=N))).astype(np.float32)
 052:     >>> arr_sig = np.sort(arr_ref + np.pi + np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=0.1, size=N)).astype(np.float32)
 053: 
 054:     The function `nearest_advocate_single_c` returns a measure of the synchronicity between both array (lower is better). 
 055: 
 056:     >>> nearest_advocate_single_c(arr_ref=arr_ref, arr_sig=arr_sig, 
 057:                                   dist_max=DEF_DIST, regulate_paddings=True,

+144: def nearest_advocate(arr_ref: np.ndarray, arr_sig: np.ndarray,
/* Python wrapper */
static PyObject *__pyx_pw_18nearest_advocate_c_3nearest_advocate(PyObject *__pyx_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_18nearest_advocate_c_2nearest_advocate[] = "Post-hoc synchronization method for event-based time-series data.\n    \n    Calculates the synchronicity of two arrays of timestamps for a search space between td_min and td_max with a precision of 1/sps. The synchronicity is given by the mean of all minimal distances between each event in arr_sig and its nearest advocate in arr_ref.\n\n    Parameters\n    ----------\n    arr_ref : 1-D ndarray\n        Reference array or timestamps assumed to be correct.\n    arr_sig : 1-D ndarray\n        Signal array of  timestamps, assumed to be shifted by an unknown constant time-delta.    \n    td_min : float\n        Lower bound of the search space for the time-shift.\n    td_max : float \n        Upper bound of the search space for the time-shift.\n    sps : int\n        Number of investigated time-shifts per second, should be higher than 10 times the number of median gap of `arr_ref` (default 10).\n    sparse_factor : int\n        Factor for the sparseness of `arr_sig` for the calculation, higher is faster but may be less accurate (default 1).\n    dist_max : float\n        Maximal accepted distances between two advocate events. It should be around 1/4 of the median gap of `arr_ref`.\n    regulate_paddings : bool\n        Regulate non-overlapping events in `arr_sig` with a maximum distance of dist_padding, default: True.\n    dist_padding : float\n        Distance assigned to non-overlapping (padding) events. It should be around 1/4 of the median gap of `arr_ref`. Obsolete if `regulate_paddings` is False\n\n    Returns\n    -------\n    nearest_ts : 2-D ndarray\n        Two-columned array with evaluated time-shifts (between `td_min` and `td_max`) and the respective mean distances. The time-delta with the lowest mean distance is the estimation for the time-shift between the two arrays.\n\n    See Also\n    --------\n    nearest_advocate\n\n    Notes\n    -----\n    .. versionadded:: 1.11.0\n\n    References\n    ----------\n    C. Schranz, S. Mayr, \"Ein neuer Algorithmus zu""r Zeitsynchronisierung von Ereignis- basierten Zeitreihendaten als Alternative zur Kreuzkorrelation\", Spinfortec (Chemnitz 2022). :doi:`10.5281/zenodo.7370958`\n\n    Examples\n    --------\n    >>> import numpy as np\n    >>> np.random.seed(0)\n    >>> from scipy.signal import nearest_advocate_c\n    >>> N = 100_000 \n    >>> DEF_DIST = 0.25    \n    \n    Create a reference array whose events differences are sampled from a normal distribution. The signal array is the reference but shifted by `np.pi` and addional gaussian noise. The event-timestamps of both arrays must be sorted.\n    \n    >>> arr_ref = np.sort(np.cumsum(np.random.normal(loc=1, scale=0.25, size=N))).astype(np.float32)\n    >>> arr_sig = np.sort(arr_ref + np.pi + np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=0.1, size=N)).astype(np.float32)\n\n    The function `nearest_advocate_c` returns a two-columned array with all investigated time-shifts and their mean distances, i.e., the measure of the synchronicity between both array (lower is better). \n    \n    >>> np_nearest = nearest_advocate_c(arr_ref=arr_ref, arr_sig=arr_sig, \n                                        td_min=-60, td_max=60, sps=20, sparse_factor=1, \n                                        dist_max=DEF_DIST, regulate_paddings=True,\n                                        dist_padding=DEF_DIST)\n    >>> time_shift, min_mean_dist = np_nearest[np.argmin(np_nearest[:,1])]\n    >>> print(time_shift, min_mean_dist)\n    3.15, 0.07941238\n    ";

  __pyx_r = __pyx_pf_18nearest_advocate_c_2nearest_advocate(__pyx_self, __pyx_v_arr_ref, __pyx_v_arr_sig, __pyx_v_td_min, __pyx_v_td_max, __pyx_v_sps, __pyx_v_sparse_factor, __pyx_v_dist_max, __pyx_v_regulate_paddings, __pyx_v_dist_padding);

 147:     """Post-hoc synchronization method for event-based time-series data.
 148:     
 149:     Calculates the synchronicity of two arrays of timestamps for a search space between td_min and td_max with a precision of 1/sps. The synchronicity is given by the mean of all minimal distances between each event in arr_sig and its nearest advocate in arr_ref.
 150: 
 151:     Parameters
 152:     ----------
 153:     arr_ref : 1-D ndarray
 154:         Reference array or timestamps assumed to be correct.
 155:     arr_sig : 1-D ndarray
 156:         Signal array of  timestamps, assumed to be shifted by an unknown constant time-delta.    
 157:     td_min : float
 158:         Lower bound of the search space for the time-shift.
 159:     td_max : float 
 160:         Upper bound of the search space for the time-shift.
 161:     sps : int
 162:         Number of investigated time-shifts per second, should be higher than 10 times the number of median gap of `arr_ref` (default 10).
 163:     sparse_factor : int
 164:         Factor for the sparseness of `arr_sig` for the calculation, higher is faster but may be less accurate (default 1).
 165:     dist_max : float
 166:         Maximal accepted distances between two advocate events. It should be around 1/4 of the median gap of `arr_ref`.
 167:     regulate_paddings : bool
 168:         Regulate non-overlapping events in `arr_sig` with a maximum distance of dist_padding, default: True.
 169:     dist_padding : float
 170:         Distance assigned to non-overlapping (padding) events. It should be around 1/4 of the median gap of `arr_ref`. Obsolete if `regulate_paddings` is False
 171: 
 172:     Returns
 173:     -------
 174:     nearest_ts : 2-D ndarray
 175:         Two-columned array with evaluated time-shifts (between `td_min` and `td_max`) and the respective mean distances. The time-delta with the lowest mean distance is the estimation for the time-shift between the two arrays.
 176: 
 177:     See Also
 178:     --------
 179:     nearest_advocate
 180: 
 181:     Notes
 182:     -----
 183:     .. versionadded:: 1.11.0
 184: 
 185:     References
 186:     ----------
 187:     C. Schranz, S. Mayr, "Ein neuer Algorithmus zur Zeitsynchronisierung von Ereignis- basierten Zeitreihendaten als Alternative zur Kreuzkorrelation", Spinfortec (Chemnitz 2022). :doi:`10.5281/zenodo.7370958`
 188: 
 189:     Examples
 190:     --------
 191:     >>> import numpy as np
 192:     >>> np.random.seed(0)
 193:     >>> from scipy.signal import nearest_advocate_c
 194:     >>> N = 100_000 
 195:     >>> DEF_DIST = 0.25    
 196:     
 197:     Create a reference array whose events differences are sampled from a normal distribution. The signal array is the reference but shifted by `np.pi` and addional gaussian noise. The event-timestamps of both arrays must be sorted.
 198:     
 199:     >>> arr_ref = np.sort(np.cumsum(np.random.normal(loc=1, scale=0.25, size=N))).astype(np.float32)
 200:     >>> arr_sig = np.sort(arr_ref + np.pi + np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=0.1, size=N)).astype(np.float32)
 201: 
 202:     The function `nearest_advocate_c` returns a two-columned array with all investigated time-shifts and their mean distances, i.e., the measure of the synchronicity between both array (lower is better). 
 203:     
 204:     >>> np_nearest = nearest_advocate_c(arr_ref=arr_ref, arr_sig=arr_sig, 
 205:                                         td_min=-60, td_max=60, sps=20, sparse_factor=1, 
 206:                                         dist_max=DEF_DIST, regulate_paddings=True,
 207:                                         dist_padding=DEF_DIST)
 208:     >>> time_shift, min_mean_dist = np_nearest[np.argmin(np_nearest[:,1])]
 209:     >>> print(time_shift, min_mean_dist)
 210:     3.15, 0.07941238
 211:     """
